marytts.signalproc.filter

Class RecursiveFilter

  • java.lang.Object
    • marytts.signalproc.filter.RecursiveFilter

  • public class RecursiveFilter
extends Object
    Author:
    Marc Schröder A purely recursive filter, following the equation: x[n] = e[n] + a[1]*x[n-1] + a[2]*x[n-2] + ... + a[p]*x[n-p]

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  RecursiveFilter.Processor 

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected double[] a
      The prediction coefficients, as in * x[n] = e[n] + a[1]*x[n-1] + a[2]*x[n-2] + ...

    • Constructor Summary

    • Field Detail

      • a

        protected final double[] a
        The prediction coefficients, as in * x[n] = e[n] + a[1]*x[n-1] + a[2]*x[n-2] + ... + a[p]*x[n-p]

    • Constructor Detail

      • RecursiveFilter

        public RecursiveFilter(double[] a)
        Create a new recursive filter.
        Parameters:
        a - the recursive prediction coefficients

    • Method Detail

      • apply

        public DoubleDataSource apply(DoubleDataSource signal)
        Apply this filter to the given input signal. The input signal is filtered piece by piece, as it is read from the data source returned by this method. This is the recommended way to filter longer signals.
        Parameters:
        signal - the signal to which this filter should be applied
        Returns:
        a DoubleDataSource from which the data can be read.

      • apply

        public double[] apply(double[] signal)
        Apply this filter to the given input signal. This method filters the entire signal, and returns the entire filtered signal. For long signals, it is better to use apply(DoubleDataSource).
        Parameters:
        signal - the signal to which this filter should be applied
        Returns:
        the filtered signal.
